sen.j: 大槻 玄沢（おおつき げんたく、宝暦7年9月28日 (旧暦)（1757年11月9日） - 文政10年3月30日 (旧暦)（1827年4月25日））は、仙台藩の支藩、一関藩（田村藩）出身の江戸時代後期の蘭学者。
sen.e: Gentaku OTSUKI (November 9, 1757 - April 25, 1827) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) from Ichinoseki Domain (Tamura Domain), a branch domain of Sendai Domain during the late Edo Period.

Gentaku OTSUKI (November 9, 1757 - April 25, 1827) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) from Ichinoseki Domain (Tamura Domain), a branch domain of Sendai Domain during the late Edo Period.

Gentaku OTSUKI (November 9, 1757 - April 25, 1827) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) from Ichinoseki Domain (Tamura Domain), a branch domain of Sendai Domain during the late Edo Period.

sen.j: 名は茂質（しげかた）、磐水と号す。
sen.e: His real name was Shigekata and he took a second name as Bansui.

sen.j: 『解体新書』の翻訳で有名な、杉田玄白・前野良沢の弟子。
sen.e: He was a disciple of Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO famous for the translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (New Book of Anatomy).
He was a disciple of Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO who were famous for the translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (New Book of Anatomy).
He was a disciple of Genpaku SUGITA and Ryotaku MAENO who were famous for the translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (New Book of Anatomy).

sen.j: 「玄沢」とは、師である二人から一文字ずつもらってつけた通り名である。
sen.e: Gentaku' is his commonly used name with a character taken from each master's name.
Gentaku' was his nickname which was taken one Chinese character from each of his two masters' names.
sen.cmt: his commonly used name → his nickname後半を変更
sen.e: Gentaku' was his nickname which was taken one Chinese character from each of his two masters' names.

sen.j: 同じ郷里の医師、建部清庵に師事し、早くから医学・語学に才能を示した。
sen.e: He studied under Seian TATEBE, a doctor from the same home town, and showed his talent for the medical science and language learning in his early ages.
He studied under Seian TATEBE, a doctor from the same hometown, and showed his talent for medical science and language when he was young.

sen.e: He studied under Seian TATEBE, a doctor from the same hometown, and showed his talent for medical science and language when he was young.

sen.j: 後に、建部清庵と手紙のやり取りをしていた杉田玄白の私塾・天真楼に学ぶ。
sen.e: Later, he studied at Tenshinro, a private school managed by Genpaku SUGITA, who was corresponding with Seian TATEBE.
Later, he studied at Tenshinro, a private school managed by Genpaku SUGITA, who exchanged letters with Seian TATEBE.
sen.cmt: was corresponding with → exchanged letters with
sen.e: Later, he studied at Tenshinro, a private school managed by Genpaku SUGITA, who exchanged letters with Seian TATEBE.

sen.j: 天明8年（1788年）、蘭学の入門書『蘭学階梯』を記したことで、蘭学界での地位を確立した。
sen.e: In 1788, he established his position in the Western studies world as a result of writing an introductory book for the Western studies, "Rangaku Kaitei."
He established himself in the world of Rangaku (Western studies) after he wrote an introductory book for the Western studies, "Rangaku Kaitei," in 1788.
sen.cmt: 「1788年」のかかりが間違えっているため訂正。
sen.e: He established himself in the world of Rangaku (Western studies) after he wrote an introductory book for the Western studies, "Rangaku Kaitei," in 1788.

sen.j: 後年には、師である杉田玄白から『解体新書』の改訂を命ぜられ、『重訂解体新書』を記している。
sen.e: In later years, he was told to revise "Kaitai Shinsho" by his master, Genpaku FUJITA, and wrote "Jutei Kaitai Shinsho" (Kaitai Shinsho Revised).

sen.j: 江戸に、私塾・芝蘭堂をひらき、多くの人材育成に当たった。
sen.e: He opened a private school named Shiran-do in Edo, and educated many students.
He opened a private school named Shiran-do in Edo, and educated many students.

sen.j: 玄沢の弟子としては、宇田川玄真、稲村三伯、橋本宗吉、山村才助の4人は特に名高く、「芝蘭堂の四天王」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Among Gentaku's disciples, especially famous were Genshin UDAGAWA, Sanpaku INAMURA, Sokichi HASHIMOTO, and Saisuke YAMAMURA, who were called 'Shitenno (the Big Four) of Shirando.'
Genshin UDAGAWA, Sanpaku INAMURA, Sokichi HASHIMOTO, and Saisuke YAMAMURA, were especially famous among Gentaku's disciples and called 'Shitenno (the Big Four) of Shirando.'
Genshin UDAGAWA, Sanpaku INAMURA, Sokichi HASHIMOTO, and Saisuke YAMAMURA, were especially famous among Gentaku's disciples and called 'Shitenno (the Big Four) of Shirando.'

sen.j: また、毎年芝蘭堂で「オランダ正月」と呼ばれる西洋の暦に合わせた新年会を開いており、ロシアへ漂流した大黒屋光太夫なども招待された。
sen.e: Besides, they threw a New Year's party according to the Western calendar at Shirando every year, which they called 'the New Year of the Netherlands,' and one of their guests was Kodayu DAIKOKUYA, who was drifted to Russia.
He also held a New Year's party called 'the Dutch New Year,' according to the Western calendar at Shirando every year, to which Kodayu DAIKOKUYA, who was drifted to Russia, and others were invited.

sen.j: 玄沢以後、大槻氏からは優秀な学者が多く輩出し、「西の頼家、東の大槻家」（頼家は頼山陽で有名）ともいわれた。
sen.e: After Gentaku, the Otsuki family produced many excellent scholars, and people called 'the Rai family in the west, the Otsuki family in the east' (the Rai family is famous for Sanyo RAI).
After Gentaku, the Otsuki family produced many excellent scholars, and people called 'the Rai family in the west, the Otsuki family in the east' (the Rai family was famous for Sanyo RAI).

sen.j: 玄沢の息子に漢学者の大槻磐渓、孫に国語学者の大槻文彦がいる。
sen.e: A son of his children was Bankei OTSUKI, a scholar of the Chinese classics, and one of his grandchildren was Fumihiko OTSUKI, a scholar of the Japanese language, and in their home town, Ichinoseki City, these three are called 'three wisdoms of Otsuki.'

sen.j: 郷里の一関市では、この3人を「大槻三賢人」と称する。
sen.e: In their hometown, Ichinoseki City, these three are called 'three wisdoms of Otsuki.'

sen.j: 養賢堂学頭の大槻平泉も同じ一族の出身である。
sen.e: A head student of Yokendo (a domain school), Heisen OTSUKI, was also from the same family.

sen.j: 仙台藩の依頼でロシア船で送り返された同藩の漂流民に事情聴取した際の記録『環海異聞』なども残されている。
sen.e: One of his writings, "Kankai-ibun" (Strange Stories from the Seas Around), records the interview with the drifted crew of Sendai Domain, who were sent back to Japan by a Russian ship, and this record was requested to write from Sendai Domain.
